comments.commentBody: I couldn't finish it either, without some help from Google--and I appreciate your confession that you couldn't finish it either--thank you!  I feel better now, especially since I "finished" it...but it is WRONG!  It was rejected!  And now I am dejected.  And, for the life of me, I can't figure out what is not correct.  I guess it's a good thing my life does not really depend on it.

I did this one surprisingly fast; for once my mind worked on the sme off trck as the constructor.  I had the "l" and the "A" of  LahainA, and put it down on spec.  Blessed if it didn't work, and that broke the top left corner. "entombs" broke the lower left. RCA Dome and Hoyt led to Abysmal to break the lower left.  It took a bit to recognize LITHELY as an adverbial synonym for "supple>supply.  Somewhere in the dim recess of my cluttered mind, Satie popped up and my flyer on it was right.  Good puzzle -- neat clues.

I'm not a purist, Patrick and felt no guilt in looking up a couple of things to help complete what was a daunting puzzle.

I didn't look up 59 Across "Supply", (answer LITHELY), but couldn't at all understand how it might fit until a light went on and I got away from the storeroom type supplies and on to supple, as lithe, as "supply". Nice misdirection, Mark.

2 down, LAHAINA was one of the few gimmes for me as the clue triggered a wonderful silly ditty I've somehow remembered over the years, written, I think, by the comedian Bill Dana as follows:

I'm going to Maui tomorrow
To marry Tamara Malone.
Nothing would be finer
Than to be in Lahaina
To make Tamara my own.

I'll smile on the isle of the valleys
And live a life of delight.
I'm going to Maui
To marry Tamara tomorrow
Unless I get lucky tonight

A super Saturday.

I FOR ONE think there were some develish clues in this one, but since I managed to finish it, I won't complain too much. "Supply" (59A) was probably the most diabolical, but so was "Counter measures?." For the latter I thought it had to be something to do with a counter in a store, so perhaps checking ID? When it's a Saturday puzzle you sometimes try to make it harder than it really is.

This may not pass the breakfast test, but 1D brought back memories of going out at night on camping trips to find good worms for bait. We used to put a metal stake into the ground and run a battery charge through it. Never worked very well.

saturdays are always really a struggle and this one took me about twice as long as usual. "i for one" was the last thing i got, because it took me a while (to get my mind supple enough, maybe) to get "lithely"

Wow, what a puzzle! It contained some virtually--though not absolutely--unfathomable clues, one of which held me hostage for many minutes over the one empty space I had left in the puzzle.

The combination of 2D and 23 and 27A, for example, crossed what, for me, were unknowns, although the middle space of 27A could only be an N or an S, and the N seemed much more likely. 1A and 9A were tricky, too, as was 35D.

Despite all its pitfalls, I was able to finish unassisted in a relatively short time for a Saturday. I'm pleased about that, but I'm even more pleased at finally catching on to the fiendishly imaginative clue at 59A. Congratulations to Mark Diehl for coming up with the mother of all misdirections.

Let us not forget that if Victor Greene (or was it Mo Lewis, memory is a bit hazy) had not put Bledsoe on the sidelines in the second (?) game of the 2001 season "The Genius" may not have ever found out what he had in Brady; after all that spring the Pats had signed Bledsoe to a 10 year $100 mil+ contract.

This was a tough puzzle, but not as hard for me as Friday's.  I did Google Great Geysir, but other than that it came together in about 1/2 hour.  I got stuck for awhile with YIN at 9D, which messed up RALSTON at 16A.  "Supply" was an amazing piece of misdirection, but once I saw ABYSMAL, which filled in DOME of RCADOME, I got the meaning of 59A.  I learned that Ngaio Marsh was a Dame, or was the British title used as a slang term for a woman?  All in all, a really good challenge!
Why don't they let the the costumers choose between a credit for the actual cost of the phone books or get the books? There are probably some people who still want the White and Yellow pages.

Don't know about you guys, but for me the problem is it used to be easy to find a phone number on the internet. Not now. It's almost impossible to get by the pay for view sites. Look up a number, sure they got it. It'll just cost you #13.95 to see it. So, I hope they don't distribute phone books anymore. But, I hope the public utility commissions make sure numbers are readily accessable for free on the internet.
We need to bail out the white page industry.
Verizon. Drop the books!

Wait... what am I supposed to use for doorstops now? Also, how will I prop up my Mac monitor?
This is a travesty!
Yep. Stop printing them.  We might reach for them once or twice, but is that worth the resources used ? NO.
Duh! I've been recycling them as soon as I get them for years.  Yellow Pages, too.
Hooray!  I take these phone books out of the mail area and throw it straight in the recycling bin.  Who with internet access uses them anymore?

The phone company should stop charging for information service if they are allowed to eliminate phone books.

Also, on-line information services should be required to supply all the same business info currently found in the yellow pages. You'd be amazed at the number of discrepencies between the phone book and an on-line search in this community. Usually the on-line source lacks info available in the phone book, though the opposite occurs too.

Please, gimme a break; it doesn't have anything to do with trees or paper, Verizon just doesn't want to be bothered with white pages or land lines or anything that doesn't make tons of money for the company. My job often requires looking up people online, and not only does it take far longer than looking in the white pages, it's uncertain and a real pain in the rear. Let people who want the printed copy have a way to get one, and the rest of you can keep paying for electricity and lithium batteries and all the other stuff required to look up numbers online. Small is beautiful.

Dropping the pulp media makes a lot of sense with so many people online via PCs, laptops, netbooks, slates and pads, and smart phones.  Those who still want the paper volumes can request them.  When trees are saved more than trees are saved. Animal  environments are preserved and more trees mean more processing of the air to remove carbon and add oxygen.  Trees also prevent land slides.

WHo still uses it? ALl the millions of people in the US in smaller cities and towns.

Good luck when you all come to visit the US National Park that surounds my home. You will NOT find the hotels or B & Bs or even most restaurants easily online. They simply do not pay for the kind of web page with all the search data inputed to show up a web search - unless you know their name and type it in. And fully 1/3rd or more don't even have a web page being small local businesses. (PS there are no chian restaurants or hotels.)

Good luck if you come to visit here and need to find a doctor or a vet. They are not listed on line.

And YAHOO ended its Yellow Pages so you can't look there.

I use the local phonebooks at least two or three times a week.
What took the phone companies so long to figure this out.
In some places, the phone books are simply thrown onto the front lawn in a plastic bag. After they have remained unclaimed for a few days, they serve as a fine "PLEASE ROB ME. I AM NOT HOME." sign.

I'm with Sara in Connecticut. I am the neighbor who picks the soggy 2 month old books up and finally throws them out. And that's the 4 different vendors all making some dumb form of a phone book. We get so many options, yellow white white & yellow, banana, it's a crazy waste. I use to live by the yellow pages but haven't touched one in probably 10 years now. Start a trend and let's hope it takes off.
About @#$!@# time ... what a colossal waste of paper, ink and transportation resources!

I find the white pages easier than online. By the time I turn on my computer and go online, I would have already found it the manual way. Plus if you are not sure of the spelling, it's easier.

However, I don't seem to receive them that frequently - I just looked at my "current" one and it says 2004!!
